turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: She came towards me with the light like it was the like light of heavenly grace, and the first thing that flashed into my gulliver was that I would like to have her right down there on the floor with the old in-out, real savage. But quick as a shot came the sickness, like a detective that had been watching around the corner and now followed to make his arrest. Alex retching. Minister rises.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Thank you very much. Thank you my dear. Girl bows and exits to loud applause.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Not feeling too bad now are you?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, sir, I feel really great.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Good.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Was I alright, sir? Did I do well, sir?

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Fine. Absolutely fine. You see, Ladies and Gentlemen our subject is, you see, impelled towards good by paradoxically being impelled toward evil. The intention to act violently is accompanied by strong feelings of physical distress. To counter these, the subject has to switch to a diametrically opposed attitude. Any questions? Priest rises and moves to Alex.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Good evening, my boy.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Hi, hi, hi there, my little droogies.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, sir, and a very lovely place it is too, sir, when I wake up in the middle of the night with my pain.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Yes... well good to see you on the mend. I've kept in constant touch with the hospital, of course, and now I've come to see you personally to see how you're getting along.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I've suffered the tortures of the damned. The tortures of the damned, sir.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Yes I can... Oh look, let me do that for you, shall I?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Thank you, sir.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: I can tell you that I... and the Government of which I am a member are deeply sorry about this, my boy. Deeply sorry. We tried to help you. We followed recommendations had been made to us that turned out to be wrong. An enquiry will place the responsibility where it belongs. We want you to regard us as friends. We've put you right, you're the best of treatments. We never wished you harm, but there are some that did and do, and I think you know who those are. There are certain people who wanted to use you for political ends. People who would have been glad to have you dead because then they would have been able to blame it all on the Government. I think you know who those are. There is also a certain man - a writer of subversive literature - who has been howling for your blood. He's been mad with desire to stick a knife into you, but you're safe from him now, we've put him away. He found out that you had done wrong to him - at least he believed you had done wrong. He had formed this idea in his head that you h

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Where is he now, sir?

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: We put him away where he can do you no harm. You see we are looking after your interests. We are interested in you, and when you leave here you will have no further worries. We shall see to everything... a good job on a good salary.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What job and how much?

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: You must have an interesting job at a salary which you would regard as adequate. Not only for the job which you are going to do and in compensation for what you believe you have suffered, but also because you are helping us.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Helping you, sir?

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: We always help our friends, don't we?  It is no secret that the Government has lost a lot of popularity because of you, my boy. There are some that think that at the next election we shall be out. The press has chosen to take a very unfavourable view of what we tried to do.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Well, who can blame them, sir?

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Mmmm, possibly. Yes. But public opinion has a way of changing and you, Alex, if I may call you, Alex?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Certainly, sir. What do they call you at home?

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: My name is Frederick. As I was saying, Alex, you can be instrumental in changing the public verdict. Do you understand, Alex? Have I made myself clear?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: As an unmuddied lake, Fred. As clear as an azure sky of deepest summer. You can rely on me, Fred.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Good... good boy. Oh yes, I understand you're fond of music. I have arranged a little surprise for you.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Surprise?

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: One I think you will like... as a, how shall I put it, as a symbol of our new understanding. An understanding between two friends.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Thank you, Fred. Thank you. Minister turns and signals. Door opens and a crowd of cameramen and reporters rush in. Aides push two 6-foot loudspeakers and a Hi-Fi on a trolley.

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Hullo lad. What a surprise, good to see you.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Keeping fit then?

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Fine, fine.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Well, how are you then?

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Oh fine, fi. Keeping out of trouble, you know.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Well - I'm back.

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Aye. Glad to see you back, lad.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: That's right, Dad they did a great job on my gulliver, I'm completely reformed.

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Aye.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Well, still the same old place then, eh?

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Oh, aye, aye.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Hey, Dad, there's a strange fella sitting on the sofa there munchy- wunching lomticks of toast.

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Aye, that's Joe. He... ummmm, lives here now. The lodger. That's what he is... he... he rents your room. Alex confronts Joe.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: How do you do, Joe? Find the room comfortable, do you? No complaints?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No thanks, Mum. It'll pass in a minute...  ... What have you done with all my own personal things?

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Well. That was all took away, son, by the Police. New regulation about compensation for the victim.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What about Basil? Where's my snake?

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Oh well, he met with like an accident. He passed away. Alex becomes a bit weepy.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What's gonna happen to me then? I mean that's my room he's in - there's no denying that. This is my home also. What suggestions have you, my Pee and Em, to make?

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Well, all this needs thinking about, son. I mean we can't very well just kick Joe out... Not just like that, can we? I mean Joe is here doing a job. A contract it is, two years. Well, we made like an arrangement, didn't we Joe? You see, son, Joe's paid next month's rent already so, well, whatever we do in the future, we cant just say to Joe to get out, now can we?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What gives, O my Pee and Em, what makes you think you are welcome? Em sobs. Pee comforts her.

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: There, there mother, it's alright. He doesn't mean it. You were in the papers again, son. It said they had done great wrong to you. It said how the Government drove you to try and do yourself in... and when you think about it, son... maybe it was our fault too in a way... your home's your home when it's all said and done, son. Em sobs.

turns.speaker: LARDFACE
turns.text: Hello, heap of dirt. Pooh, you don't wash much do you, judging by the horrible smell.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Why do you say that, brother? I had a shower this morning.

turns.speaker: LARDFACE
turns.text: Oh, he had a shower this morning. You trying to call me a liar?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, brother. What d'you want?

turns.speaker: LARDFACE
turns.text: What do I want?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Sorry, brother. I didn't mean any offence.

turns.speaker: LARDFACE
turns.text: Oh. Oh, you're sorry are you, well you must think I'm awfully stupid. He slaps Alex in the face.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Why did you do that, brother? I've never done wrong to you.

turns.speaker: LARDFACE
turns.text: You want to know why I did that, well you see - I do that... He stamps on Alex's foot.

turns.speaker: LARDFACE
turns.text: ... and this... He pulls Alex's nose.

turns.speaker: LARDFACE
turns.text: ... and that... He pulls Alex's ear, pushes him off balance and plants his foot on his chest.

turns.speaker: LARDFACE
turns.text: ... because I don't like you horrible type, do I, and if you want to start something... if you want to start... go on... well, you just start. Please do. Alex retching.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I'm gonna be sick.

turns.speaker: LARDFACE
turns.text: You're gonna be sick are you?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I wanna be sick.

turns.speaker: LARDFACE
turns.text: You wanna be sick?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Let me get up.

turns.speaker: LARDFACE
turns.text: You wanna get up? Well, you've gotta you see... well I want you to lick it. Go on... Lick it. Alex, gagging and coughing, licks the sole of his shoe.

turns.speaker: LARDFACE
turns.text: ... And again... Go on!!! Again! There's a good boy.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: And, O my brothers, would you believe your faithful friend and long suffering narrator pushed out his red yahzik a mile and a half to lick the grahzny, vonny boots. The horrible killing sickness had wooshed up and turned the like joy of battle into a feeling I was going to snuff it. Minister rises.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: You are now in H.M. Prison Parkmoor and from this moment you will address all prison officers as sir! Name?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Alexander de Large, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Crime?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Murder, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Right. Take the cuffs off him, Mister. The cuffs are removed.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Then your toes belong on the other side of it!!!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Right carry on. Alex tosses a bar of chocolate on the desk.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Pick that up and put it down properly. Alex does so, and continues to empty his pockets.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: One half bar of chocolate. One bunch of keys on white metal ring. One packet of cigarettes. Two plastic ball pens - one black, one red. One pocket comb - black plastic. One address book - imitation red leather. One ten penny piece. One white metal wristlet watch, "Timawrist" on a white metal expanding bracelet. Anything else in your pockets?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Right. Sign here for your valuable property. Alex signs.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: The chocolate and cigarettes you brought in - you lose that as you are now convicted. Now go over to the table and get undressed. Alex walks to table and undresses. Chief Guard moves to table with his clipboard.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Now then, were you in Police custody this morning?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Religion?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: C of E, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Do you mean Church of England?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, sir, Church of England, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Brown hair, is it?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Fair hair, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Blue eyes?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Blue eyes, yes, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Do you wear eye glasses or contact lenses?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Have you ever had any mental illness?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Do you wear any false teeth or false limbs?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Are you an Epileptic?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Right. The mothballs, Mister.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Crabs?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Lice?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Through there for a bath.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes, sir.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You're absolutely right, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Shut your bleedin' hole!!!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: The next morning I was taken to the Ludovico Medical Facility, outside the town centre, and I felt a malenky bit sad having to say goodbye to the old Staja, as you always will when you leave a place you've like gotten used to. Chief Guard briskly leads the way for Alex and escort. They move into reception hall where the Doctor stands.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Right. Halt the prisoner. Good morning, sir, I'm Chief Officer Barnes. I've got 655321 on a transfer from Parkmoor to the Ludovico Centre, sir!

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: Good morning, Alex, my name is Dr. Branom. I'm Doctor Brodsky's assistant.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Good Morning, Missus. Lovely day, isn't it?

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: Indeed it is. May I take this She removes his tray.

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: How're you feeling this morning?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Fine... fine.

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: Good. In a few minutes, you'll meeting Dr. Brodsky and we'll begin your treatment. You're a very lucky boy to have been chosen.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I realise all that, Missus, and I'm very grateful to all concerned.

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: We're going to friends now, sir.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I hope so, Missus. She inserts a needle into the medicine vial.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What's the hypo for then? Going to send me to sleep?

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: Oh no, nothing of the sort.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Vitamins will it be then?

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: Something like that. You are a little undernourished, so after each meal were going to give you a shot. Roll over on your right side please, loosen your pyjama pants and pull them half-way down. He does, somewhat reluctantly. She gives him a shot in the bum.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What exactly is the treatment here going to be then?

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: It's quite simple really. Were just going to show you some films.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You mean like going to the pictures?

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: Something like that.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Well, that's good. I like to viddy the old films now and again.

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: Well, that was a very promising start. By my calculations, you should be starting to feel alright again. Yes? Dr. Brodsky's pleased with you. Now tomorrow there'll be two sessions, of course, morning and afternoon.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You mean, I have to viddy two sessions in one day?

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: I imagine you'll be feeling a little bit limp by the end of the day. But we have to be hard on you. You have to be cured.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: But it was horrible.

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: Well, of course, it was horrible. Violence is a very horrible thing. That's what you're learning now. Your body is learning it.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I just don't understand about feeling sick the way I did. I never used to feel sick before. I used to feel like the very opposite. I mean, doing it or watching it, I used to feel real horrorshow. I just don't understand why, how what.

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: You felt ill this afternoon because you're getting better. You see, when we're healthy we respond to the presence of the hateful with fear and nausea. You're becoming healthy that's all. By this time tomorrow you'll be healthier still.

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: Are you referring to the background score?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes!!!

turns.speaker: DR. BRANOM
turns.text: You've heard Beethoven before?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes!!!

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: How are you feeling today?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Fine. Fine.

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Good. I'm doctor Taylor.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I haven't seen you before.

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: I'm your Psychiatrist.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Psychiatrist? Huh, do I need one?

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Just part of hospital routine.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: What are we going to do? Talk about me sex life?

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: No... I'm going to show you some slides and you are going to tell me what you think about them Alright?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Ohhh... jolly good. Perhaps you can explain me something to me first.

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Yes?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Well, when I was all like ashamed up and half awake and unconscious like, I kept having this dream like all these doctors were playing around with me gulliver. You know... like the inside of me brain. I seemed to have this dream over and over again. D'you think it means anything?

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Patients who've sustained the kind of injuries you have often have dreams of this sort. It's all part of the recovery process.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Oh.

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Now then, each of these slides needs a reply from one of the people in the picture. You'll tell me what you think the person would say. Alright?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Righty, right. The doctor reads aloud the dialogue printed in the cartoon balloon - a peacock.

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Isn't the plumage beautiful?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I just say what the other person would say?

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Yes. Yes, well don't think about it too long, just say the first thing that pops into your mind.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Right... Knickers... Cabbages... It doesn't have a beak. Alex laughs. Slide of woman speaking to boy.

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Good. The boy you always quarrelled with is seriously ill.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: That's right and I'll smash your face for you, yarblockos. Slide of watch shop.

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Good. It wa your fault... you sold me a crummy watch. I want my money back.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Bollocks. You know what you can do with that watch? You can stick it up your arse. Slide of nude woman in bed, a man at the window.

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Good. What do you want?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Excuse me, missus. No time for the old in-out, I've just come to read the meter. Slide of bird's nest with eggs.

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Good. You can do whatever you like with these.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Eggiwegs. I would like to smash 'em. Pick up th elot and f... owww... He slams his hand down and cries out with pain.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Fucking hell...

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Fine. Well, that's all there is to it. Are you alright?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I hope so. Is that the end then?

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I was quite enjoying that.

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: Good. I'm glad

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: How many did I get right?

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: It's not that kind of a test. But you seem well on the way to a complete recovery.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: And when do I get out of here then?

turns.speaker: DR. TAYLOR
turns.text: I'm sure it won't be long now.

turns.speaker: DR. BRODSKY
turns.text: Very soon now the drug will cause the subject to experience a death- like paralysis together with deep feelings of terror and helplessness. One of our earlier test subjects described it as being like death, a sense of stifling and drowning, and it is during this period we have found the subject will make his most rewarding associations between his catastrophic experience and environment and the violence he sees. Alex retching violently and struggling against his strait jacket.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Let me be sick... I want to get up. Get me something to be sick in... Stop the film... Please stop it... I can't stand it any more. Stop it please... please.

turns.speaker: DR. BRODSKY
turns.text: What's all this about sin?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: That!... Using Ludwig van like that! He did no harm to anyone. Beethoven just wrote music.

turns.speaker: DR. BRODSKY
turns.text: You're keen on music?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Yes!!!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: You needn't take it any further, sir. You've proved to me that all this ultra-violence and killing is wrong and terribly wrong. I've learned my lesson, sir. I see now what I've never seen before I'm cured, praise Bog!

turns.speaker: DR. BRODSKY
turns.text: You're not cured yet, my boy.

turns.speaker: DR. BRODSKY
turns.text: You must take your chance boy. The choice has been all yours.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: But, Sir... Missus... I see that it's wrong! It's wrong because it's like against like society. It's wrong because everybody has the right to live and be happy without being tolchocked and knifed.

turns.speaker: DR. BRODSKY
turns.text: No, no, boy. You really must leave it to us, but be cheerful about it. In less than a fortnight now, you'll be a free man.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: One thing I could never stand is to see a filthy, dirty old drunkie, howling away at the filthy songs of his fathers and going blerp, blerp in between as it might be a filthy old orchestra in his stinking rotten guts. I could never stand to see anyone like that, whatever his age might be, but more especially when he was real old like this one was. The boys stop and applaud him.

turns.speaker: TRAMP
turns.text: Can you... can you spare some cutter, me brothers? Alex rams his stick into the Tramp's stomach. The boys laugh.

turns.speaker: TRAMP
turns.text: Oh-hhh!!! Go on, do me in you bastard cowards. I don't want to live anyway, not in a stinking world like this.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Oh - and what's so stinking about it?

turns.speaker: TRAMP
turns.text: It's a stinking world because there's no law and order any more. It's a stinking world because it lets the young get onto the old like you done. It's no world for an old man any more. What sort of a world is it at all? Men on the moon and men spinning around the earth and there's not no attention paid to earthly law and order no more. The Tramp starts singing again.

turns.speaker: TRAMP
turns.text: Can you spare me some cutter, me brother? Can you spare some cutter, me brother? Alex, without looking at him, reaches in his pocket and gives him some money.

turns.speaker: TRAMP
turns.text: Oh, thankyou, your honour. The Tramp takes a second look at Alex.

turns.speaker: TRAMP
turns.text: Jamey Mack! Be the hokey fly! Holy Mother of God! All the Holy Angels and blessed saints in Heaven preserve us. Alex breaks away but the Tramp toddles alongside him.

turns.speaker: TRAMP
turns.text: I never forget a face! I never forget any face, be God!

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Leave me alone, brother. I've never seen you before. Tramp shouts to other Meths drinkers and Tramps.

turns.speaker: TRAMP
turns.text: This is the poisonous young swine that near done me in. Him and his friends beat me and kicked me and thumped me. Alex breaks away again.

turns.speaker: TRAMP
turns.text: Stop him! Stop him! A leg is stuck out and Alex goes down. The tramp swarm all over him.

turns.speaker: TRAMP
turns.text: They laughed at me blood and me moans. This murderous young pig is a prize specimen of the cowardly brutal young. He is in our midst and at our mercy. Give it to him. That's it. Old Tramps begin to beat at Alex.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Then there was like a sea of dirty, smelly old men trying to get at your humble Narrator, with their feeble rookers and horny old claws. It was Old Age having a go at Youth and I daren't do a single solitary thing, O my brothers, it being better to be hit at like that, than want to be sick and feel that horrible pain. The Tramp crowd round Alex, shouting.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: If thou lose hope being weary in the days of distress, thy strength shall be diminished.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Fine, my boy, fine, fine.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Father, I have tried, have I not?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: You have, my son.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I've done my best, have I not?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Indeed.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: And, Father, I've never been guilty of any institutional infractions, have I?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: You certainly have not, 655321. You've been very helpful, and you've shown a genuine desire to reform.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Father - may I ask you a question in private?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Certainly, my son, certainly. Is there something troubling you, my son? Don't be shy to speak up. Remember, I know all the urges that can trouble young men deprived of the society of women.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: No Father. It's nothing like that, Father. It's about this new thing they're all talking about. About this new treatment that you out of prison in no time at all and makes sure you never get back in again.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Where did you hear about this? Whose been talking about these things?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: These things get around, Father. Two Warders talk as it might be, and somebody can't help overhearing what they say. Then somebody picks up a scrap of newspaper in the workshops and the newspaper tells all about it. How about putting me in for this new treatment, Father?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: I take it you are referring to the Ludovico Technique?

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I don't know what it's called, Father, all I know is that it gets you out quickly and makes sure that you never get in again.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: That's not proven, 655321. In fact, it is only in the experimental stage at this moment.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: But it is being used, isn't it, Father?

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: It has not been used yet in this prison. The Governor has grave doubts about it and I have heard that there are very serious dangers involved.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I don't care about the danger, Father. I just want to be good. I want for the rest of my life to be one act of goodness.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: The question is weather or not this technique really makes a man good. Goodness comes from within. Goodness is chosen. When a man cannot chose, he ceases to be a man.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: I don't understand about the whys and wherefores, Father. I only know I want to be good.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Be patient, my son, and put your trust in the Lord.

turns.speaker: ALEX
turns.text: Instruct thy son and he shall refresh thee and shall give delight to thy soul.

turns.speaker: PRIEST
turns.text: Amen. They cross themselves.

turns.speaker: CHECK-IN
turns.text: One jacket - blue pinstripe.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Prison custody?

turns.speaker: CHECK-IN
turns.text: One shirt - blue, collar attached.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Have you been receiving medical treatment for any serious illness?

turns.speaker: CHECK-IN
turns.text: One pair of trousers - blue pinstriped.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Have you ever had any attacks of fainting or dizziness?

turns.speaker: CHECK-IN
turns.text: One pair of underpants - white with blue waistband.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Are you now, or ever have been, a homosexual?

turns.speaker: CHECK-IN
turns.text: Mothballs, sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Now then. Face the wall. Bend over and touch your toes. Chief Guard inspects Alex's anus with a penlight.

turns.speaker: GOVERNOR
turns.text: Very good, Chief. They inspect cells.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Leave to carry on, sir, please?

turns.speaker: GOVERNOR
turns.text: Carry on, Chief.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Sir.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Sir, 655321, sir.

turns.speaker: GOVERNOR
turns.text: Very good, Chief. Chief Guard turns to Alex.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Forward to the white line, toes behind it. Full name and number to the Governor. Chief Guard closes door.

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Shut your filthy hole, you scum!!!

turns.speaker: GOVERNOR
turns.text: You are to be reformed. Tomorrow you go to this man, Brodsky. You wbe leaving here. You will be transferred to the Ludovico Medical Facility. It is believed that you will be able to leave State custody in a little over a fortnight. I suppose that prospect pleases you?

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Answer when the Governor asks you a question you filthy young swine!

turns.speaker: CHIEF GUARD
turns.text: Don't read it - sign it!

turns.speaker: GOVERNOR
turns.text: It says that you are willing to have the residue of your sentence commuted to the Ludovico treatment. Alex signs. Governor gathers up papers. Alex dots the last "i" and smiles.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Pitiful rookerful...

turns.speaker: GEORGIE
turns.text: And there's Will the English in the Muscleman coffee mesto saying he can fence anything that anything that any malchick tries to crast.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Yeah... Pete the English.

turns.speaker: GEORGIE
turns.text: The shiny stuff. The Ice. The big, big, big money is available's what Will the English says.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Big, big money.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: Moloko-plus.

turns.speaker: GEORGIE
turns.text: Something to sharpen us up, you especially. We have the start.

turns.speaker: GEORGIE
turns.text: Enough is remembered though, little Alex. Dim and Georgie laugh. They drag Alex to a low water through.

turns.speaker: DIM
turns.text: This is to make sure you stay cured. Georgie hits Alex in the stomach with his blackjack. Then, they push his head under the water and methodically start to beat him with their blackjacks. After a full minute of this, they drag him out, halt-drowned,

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Yes, I heard. D'you know what time he got in last night?

turns.speaker: EM
turns.text: No I don't know, luv, I'd taken my sleepers.

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: I wonder where exactly is it he goes to work of evenings.

turns.speaker: EM
turns.text: Well, like he says, it's mostly odd things he does, helping like... here and there, as it might be.

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Well, it's a surprise all right, a bit bewildering too.

turns.speaker: EM
turns.text: We've only just read about it in the morning papers.

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Aye. You should have let us know, lad, not that we're not very pleased to see you again. All cured too, eh?

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Well, what's the matter lad, are you feeling alright?

turns.speaker: EM
turns.text: Dad... It's the treatment. More retching.

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: D'you think we should do something?

turns.speaker: EM
turns.text: Would you like me to make you a nice cup of tea, son?

turns.speaker: EM
turns.text: Hullo, son, how are you?

turns.speaker: PEE
turns.text: Are you feeling better?

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: How many to a cell?

turns.speaker: GOVERNOR
turns.text: Four in this block, sir.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Cram criminals together and what do you get - concentrated criminality... crime in the midst of punishment.

turns.speaker: GOVERNOR
turns.text: I agree, sir. What we need are larger prisons. More money.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Not a chance, my dear fellow. The Ggovernment can't be concerned any longer with outmoded penological theories. Soon we may be needing all of out prison space for political offenders. Common criminals like these are best dealt with on a purely curative basis. Kill the criminal reflex that's all. Full implementation in a year's time. Punishment means nothing to them, you can see that... they enjoy their so-called punishment. Alex seizes his chance as they pass by.

turns.speaker: GOVERNOR
turns.text: Well, fine... we could still look at C-Block.

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: No, no, no. That's enough. He's perfect. I want his records sent to me. This vicious young hoodlum will be transformed out of all recognition.

turns.speaker: GOVERNOR
turns.text: Shall we go to my office?

turns.speaker: MINISTER
turns.text: Thank you.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Hi ya' doin'?  Where to?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Park Avenue and East 2nd. Take Centre to Canal, up the Bowery, Cooper and Third, left on 41st, come around on Park.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I'll take Sixth.  It's faster.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Sixth is faster.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Sixth is a parking lot north of 23rd this time of day.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: The Bowery, you gotta deal with runoff from two bridges.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Sixth, you got delivery trucks blocking traffic at Herald Square. Look, I make this trip all the time.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: First Friday of the month?  Linens. Roll right off the trucks.  They're in and out in twenty minutes...  ...which means they left fifteen minutes ago.  Traffic will be smooth.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: But Bowery's fine, if that's what you want.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: We taking bets?  What if you're wrong?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: The ride is free.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You got a deal.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Go ahead, say it.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: No.  I got lucky with the lights.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No.  You were right, I was wrong...  ...Max.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You like Bach?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: I used to play this piece back in high school.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Let me guess.  Clarinet?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Violin.  I never had the lungs for wind instruments.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Could'a fooled me, the way you were hollering into that cell phone.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Different instrument altogether.  You know, if you'd only listened to me, we'd be bogged down in traffic right now, and you could have made yourself an extra five bucks.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Keep it.  Go wild.  Have a party.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Why'd you do that?  Don't tell me you're a gentleman, Max. I thought chivalry was dead as a necessary consequence of gender politics...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: It's no big deal.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No?  How many cabbies get you into an argument to save you money?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: There were two of us.  I had the other guy killed.  Don't need the competition...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You're an anomaly in today's world, Max.  You're good at what you do, so you must take pride in it...?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: This?  Temporary.  To pay the bills and save. I got plans...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Like what?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Travel...and things.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You like being a lawyer?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: You psychic?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Sure.  I'm starting an 800 hotline.  Caught part of your phone call.  And even if I hadn't, there's the dark pinstripe, Armani, elegant, not too hip, which rules out advertising, plus a top-of-the-line briefcase that you live out of, looks like Bottega...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Bottega.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: ...Bottega.  Guy gets in my cab wearing a catcher's mask, I think he's a ballplayer.  You?  Definitely Clarence Darrow.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Not quite.  He did defense.  I'm a prosecutor...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Big case?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Yeah.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You never answered my question.  You like what you do?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Most of the time.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: But not now?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Like you, I'm good at it.  But at this exact moment in time...like I gotta sumo wrestler on my shoulders until tomorrow morning.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You need a vacation.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Just had one.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Not in a cab...  I mean a disconnection...get your head straight...you know, get it together...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: When was the last time you took one?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Soon.  But I take little ones all the time.  Comoros Islands in the Indian Ocean.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: How often you go?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Dozen times a day.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: No, no way, I couldn't take that...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Yes, you could.  I think you need it more than I do.  It'll help.  I promise.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Thanks for everything, Max.  Wow...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Sure thing.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Annie...it's Max.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Max...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Max, the cab driver!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Max?  Oh...  ...it's kind of a strange time to be calling...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Listen to me!  Just listen, okay? There's a man, Vincent, he's coming to kill you!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: He's...what?  Say again?  We're in cell hell...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: <u>Kill</u> you!  He's coming to kill you!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: If this is a joke, it's not funny.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Dmitri hired him!  He's already killed all your witnesses, now he's coming after you!  He was stalking you when I dropped you off.  I don't know what happened, but he diverted and got into my cab, instead.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Did you say <u>Dmitri?</u> How do you know about my case?  I don't understand...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: It doesn't matter!  Just get out of the goddamn building...

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: ...okay, Max, I believe you...I'll get out of the building...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: No, no, <u>wait</u>...

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: ...he's two floors below you.

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: In my office?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Where are you, what floor?

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Seventh, files section.  What should I do?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: He doesn't know you're up there!  Just stay right where you are!  Call the police!

turns.speaker: ANNIE
turns.text: Max, I'm scared.  Are you sure?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Yes!  Stay put, goddamn it!  Don't move from that spot...

turns.speaker: COP #1
turns.text: This your current address?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Yes.

turns.speaker: COP #1
turns.text: A deer?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Comin' over Coldwater.  Goddamn deer jumps out in front of me.  You believe that?

turns.speaker: COP #1
turns.text: You still carrying passengers?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I was heading back to my garage.  It's on the way.

turns.speaker: COP #1
turns.text: This vehicle's not safe to drive. We're gonna have to impound it.  Get you towed.  Step away from the vehicle and pop the trunk.  I'm sorry, sir, you'll have to find another cab.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Come on, it's been a long, shitty day. How about a break?  I'll call a tow truck myself, I swear.  I won't budge from this spot.

turns.speaker: COP #1
turns.text: Save me the grief.  Step out of the car, sir, and open the trunk.

turns.speaker: COP #1
turns.text: You dizzy?  You want to sit down?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I'm...fine.  Fine.

turns.speaker: COP #1
turns.text: You sure?  You look pretty shaky...

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: ...I was just a young cat back then, about nineteen, bussin' tables in this very place.  Didn't pay but shit, but that wasn't the point.  Being around the music, that was the thing.  And I was.  Take this one night...July 22, 1964...who walks in?  Mr. Louis Armstrong.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: You're kidding me.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Right through those doors.  The man himself.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: Jesus...

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: He'd come over from Queens to do the Ed Sullivan show.  After, he decides to come on up to Harlem and hang with the common folk.  That's how he was, you see.  Never forgot where he came from.  Money and fame an' all that?  Meant nothin', long as he could blow that horn.  So before you it, he's up on that stage, doin' his thing.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: Was it great?  Better than great, it had to be...

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Like Winton Marsalis says, it was pure, spiritual essence.  Louis was playing.  God was smiling.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: You heard Armstrong play live.  I've never been this jealous.  You get to talk to him?

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Did better'n that.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: No.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Oh, my, yes.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: Get outta here!  You and Louis?

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Fella owned this place back then, Dix Dwyer, he let slip to Louis that I played.  So Pops, he just waves me right up.  My heart about stopped. But I got up there all the same, and we played for nearly twenty minutes.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: Unbelievable...  ...you hearing this?  Unbelievable.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: Remember what you played?

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Most vividly.  "St. Louis Blues," "Potato Head Blues," "Sleepy Time Down South..."  ...then Pops laid some "Cornet Chop Suey" on me, and left me in the dust like a whipped dog.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: The crowd had to dig it.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: The crowd was most kind.  I was born in 1945, but my life began the night of July 22, 1964.  That was the moment of my conception.  Right here in this very room.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: You know Dmitri?

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: 'Fraid so.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: And here I was thinking you were such a nice guy.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: I am a nice guy, Daniel.  With a job to do.  You know how it is.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: What kind of question?

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: Jazz question.  What other kind is there?  You get it right, we roll with it.  You disappear.  Tonight.  You don't go home, you don't pack a bag, you just leave town...and nobody, I mean nobody, ever hears from you or sees you again.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: How do I know you'll keep your word?

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: I never lie.  Ask Max.  Max, have I lied yet?

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: One more thing.  If by some chance I get this wrong...tell Dmitri I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: Of course.

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: Lay it on me.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: It's simple.  What was your pal Louis' first musical instrument?

turns.speaker: DANIEL
turns.text: I know the answer.  I know all there is to know about Louis.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: Then let's have it.

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: I see.  That was an important list, wouldn't you say?  The people on that list are being subpoenaed tomorrow by a federal judge.  And you "lost" it?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I'm sorry.

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: Sorry?

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: Tell me, Vincent.  Do you believe in Santa Claus?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Can't say that I do.

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: Neither do I.  But my children, they're still young.  Do you know who they like even more than jolly old Saint Nicholas?  His helper, Black Peter. An old Russian fairy tale tells of how Santa got so busy looking after all the good kids, he had to hire a helper to punish all the bad kids.  That was Black Peter's job.  He was given the list of all the bad children, and he would visit them in their homes late at night.  And if he caught them not saying their prayers, he would leave a bundle of wooden switches outside their door.  That was a warning.  If they continued to misbehave, he would swoop down and take the children away. And they would never be seen again.

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: Tell me Vincent.  Tell me what you think.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I think...

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: What?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I think...  ...I think you should get this gun out of my fucking face.

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: What?  What did you say?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I said.  Get the gun.  Out.  Of my fucking <u>face.</u> Before I wrap it in a blintz and feed it to you.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: I picked up a tail.

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: Federal?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You tell me.  I had to toss the list in the river.  I was protecting your sorry, long-winded ass.  So why don't you show a little courtesy?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: You think I wanted to come here tonight?  You think I'm that stupid? Sometimes shit happens, you gotta roll with it.

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: Tell me.  Has Black Peter already crossed off a few bad children?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: The fat man on Cherry Street.  The other fat man, Mr. Bulldozer.  The trumpet player.  That leaves two.

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: Can you finish on schedule?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: In fifteen years, I have never left a customer unsatisfied.

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: Vincent.  Do not cross me.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Wouldn't dream of it.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: As a token of my appreciation for your understanding in this matter, I'd like to offer you a discount for my services tonight.  Twenty five percent.

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: Twenty five?

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: Hell, make it fifty.  Same goes for any business we have in the future.

turns.speaker: DMITRI
turns.text: Very generous.

turns.speaker: MAX
turns.text: By the way.  Daniel said he was sorry.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Something going on?

turns.speaker: PEDROSA
turns.text: Pretty quiet down there.  A cab just pulled up, aside from that...

turns.speaker: PEDROSA
turns.text: ...goddamn it, you telling me this motherfucker's whacked three of our witnesses tonight...

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: ...Petrov and Cicerno for sure...

turns.speaker: PEDROSA
turns.text: Advance team, two men, stick to that goddamn cab, stay in radio contact, the rest of us follow in the van. Nobody moves until the entire team's in place...

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Can you fax me his picture?  His license or something?  What do you mean you don't have that there?  Anybody else in the cab?

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: ...got off the phone with his dispatcher.  What an asshole. Cabbie's name is Max Rilke, been driving that cab for ten years...

turns.speaker: PEDROSA
turns.text: So?

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: ...so, his description of Max the cabdriver matches the guy who walked out of Villa Rodeo.  That guy?  That guy is a cabbie.  And you're telling me this cabbie walks into a phone booth and emerges as a meat eater, assassin with heavy trigger time? What's he do, squeeze 'em in between fares?

turns.speaker: PEDROSA
turns.text: No.  Your cabbie is floating down a storm drain or stuffed in the trunk of a cab.

turns.speaker: PEDROSA
turns.text: Lemme tell you something.  Vincent and a few other guys like him are fucking ghosts.  Nobody even know what he looked like until now...

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: I don't know...

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: What are you gonna do?

turns.speaker: PEDROSA
turns.text: Take him down.  Save Richard Yip, our witness...

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: ...this snitch of yours, what's his name, Ivan?

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Ivan Petrov.  Supposed to meet me for dinner, never shows up.  I come here, find this.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: You guys been holding hands?

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Months now.  He's been feeding me information on Dmitri.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Dmitri <u>Gusunov?</u> What the fuck, why? Forget about Dimitri, Feds are all over him.  They're a heartbeat away from taking him down.  Word's gone out, they don't want us anywhere near him...

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Oh, we working for the Feds now?  If my snitch flew out a window, he's got Dmitri's handprints on his ass. That makes it homicide, that makes it ours.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: What homicide?  Phil.  Where's a body? Look.  All we got is glass...

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: There was a car here, you can see where the glass came down all around it.  Ivan flew out the window and went bam.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: He could'a been depressed.  It still doesn't tell me homicide.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Remember that thing a few years back? That thing with the cab?

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: What thing?

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Cabbie drove around all night.  Three people got killed.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Oh, right.  The guy flipped out or something?  Killed some people, then put a gun to his own head?

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: They found him dead in his own cab down by the Port Authority.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: So?  It was a random thing.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: I never bought that.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Oh?

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Cabbie had no criminal record, no history of mental illness.  Suddenly, he just wigs out and pops three people, then himself?  Plus the victims weren't random solid citizens. They were all lowlives.  Wiseguys.  I've always wondered if there was someone else in the cab.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: ...yeah, I'm still at Bellevue.  The John Doe didn't pan out, but you'll never guess who's lying up in the meat locker.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Elvis?

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Joey Cicerno.  Dear friend and associate of my missing snitch, Ivan Petrov.  Both of whom were in bed with Dmitri.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Jesus.  Two in one night?

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Something big's going down, and I'm betting the Feds don't know about it. You gotta get us in there.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Pick me up in five minutes.

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Captain Walt Muldoon, NYPD.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: Detective Sergeant Phil Heller.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: What if they're wrong?

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: Not our call, Phil.

turns.speaker: HELLER
turns.text: ...if they're wrong?!

turns.speaker: MULDOON
turns.text: This isn't our goddamn game!

turns.speaker: IDA
turns.text: Why didn't you tell me we had company?  And what's your name?

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: No harm done, ma'am.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: Happy to meet you, Mrs. Rilke.

turns.speaker: IDA
turns.text: Oh, call me Ida.  To what do we owe the pleasure?

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: I was with Max when he got the call.

turns.speaker: IDA
turns.text: And you came all the way down here to see me?

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: It's nothing.

turns.speaker: IDA
turns.text: Tell my son.  You have to hold a gun to his head to get him to come see me.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: Tell me about it.

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: Client?  I like to think of myself as more of a friend.  A mentor.

turns.speaker: IDA
turns.text: Max never had many friends.  So much with the piano.  Always keeping to himself, it's unhealthy...

turns.speaker: VINCENT
turns.text: I'm sure you're very proud of Max.

turns.speaker: IDA
turns.text: Of course I'm proud.  You know he started with nothing?  Look at him today.  Playing concerts.
